awd_titl_txt: Managing Forests for Snow, Water, and Sustainable Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
In western North America, forest management strategies have led to young, dense forests that are more susceptible to drought, insect infestation, and other stressors. Forests cover 30% of the earth's land area and almost 100% of many U.S. mountainous regions.  Thus, a change in forest structure has broad ecological impacts, beyond those normally attributed to climate change.  The PI has shown forest cover may either increase or decrease the date of the first snowmelt by up to two weeks. As mountainous snowpacks are a natural water storage reservoir, the date of the first snowmelt affects summer river flow.  Summer river flow has wide ranging impacts on human, ecosystem, and agricultural water demands. The effect of forest cover may be managed by increasing forest retention and/or opening gaps in the canopy. This research project is developing and testing hydrologic models for mountainous watersheds to determine how forest change relates to the human-ecologic-hydrologic system.  Additionally, the researchers on this project are working with stakeholders to help students understand the goals and concerns related to forest-water management and educating undergraduate and graduate students in state-of-the-art spatial data analysis and modeling.

Forest managers would like to know what site-specific actions to take for both sustainable water and forest management. Light Detection and Ranging (Lidar) is a remote sensing method that uses light in the form of a pulsed laser to measure distances to the Earth. Lidar imaging, combined with spatially-explicit modeling, represent a break-through in forest structure characterization and its relation to forest-snow interactions. This research project is utilizing and adapting an existing distributed hydrologic model to be used as a tool to assist forest management decisions. Specifically, the project involves modifying the model to better represent complex forest-snow interactions; using high resolution aerial photos combined with forest and snow lidar datasets to extract meaningful model parameters and to check simulated fields; testing model reliability over varying winter weather regimes; testing model transferability between sites with different forests and climate regimes, and working with an advisory team to distribute the model and tools so that they can be applied to any watershed.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation:

In winter, snow covers about 50% of the land surface in the northern hemisphere, and approximately 50% of this snow zone is also forested.  Forests worldwide are rapidly changing, due to fires, insects, drought, and harvesting, and combined forest-snow changes impact water availability and streamflow timing.  While monitoring and predicting these changes are critical, remote sensing struggles to detect snow below trees, and model uncertainty is high due to the complex processes involved. 

 

Intellectual Merit:

As outcomes of this project, we learned that airborne lidar accurately measures snow depths below forest canopy (Currier et al., 2019; Mazzotti et al., 2019), and forest gaps and edges control snow distributions (Currier & Lundquist, 2018).  Snow distribution patterns shaped by wind play an important role, but downscaling mountain winds requires both a high resolution (~3 km) atmospheric model and a physically-based scheme for downscaling those winds to finer resolutions (Reynolds et al., 2021). Explicitly representing forest structure in models changes simulated streamflow in the Pacific Northwest, particularly during low flows (Sun et al. 2018), but the magnitude and direction of simulated change varies widely with location and climate (Currier et al. 2021; Sun et al. 2021).  Only a subset of land surface models contain enough interception physics to be transferable between climates, due primarily to a lack of observations (Lundquist et al., 2021).  Fortunately, photos analyzed by citizen scientists provide a new means to obtain these needed observations (Lumbrazo et al., 2021). 

 

Broader Impacts:       

The project led to the promotion of the project postdoc to a permanent Research Scientist position, to 2 M.S. degrees, 1 Ph.D., and the mentoring of 1 undergraduate researcher.  The project involved over 7,700 citizen scientists on Zooniverse who classified snow in time-lapse photos to guide modeling of canopy snow unloading (Lumbrazo et al., 2021). Understanding forest and snow interactions is important across the western U.S. as resource managers try to optimize both fire protection and water supplies.  Project personnel provided guidance to forest-water management projects, both through participation in meetings and a targeted publication (Dickerson-Lange et al., 2021).

 

References: 

Currier, W. R., & Lundquist, J. D. (2018). Snow depth variability at the forest edge in multiple climates in the western United States. Water Resources Research, 54(11), 8756-8773.

Currier, W. R., Pflug, J., Mazzotti, G., Jonas, T., Deems, J. S., Bormann, K. J., et al. (2019). Comparing aerial lidar observations with terrestrial lidar and snow‐probe transects from NASA's 2017 SnowEx campaign. Water Resources Research, 55(7), 6285-6294.

Currier, W. R., Sun, N., Wigmosta, M. S., Cristea, N., & Lundquist, J. D. (2021). Subgrid forest-snow tiling in a distributed hydrological model and its effect on late-season streamflow in multiple western U.S. climates. submitted to Water Resources Research.

Dickerson-Lange, S., Gersonde, R., Vano, J. A., & Lundquist, J. (2021). Ranking forest effects on snow storage: a decision tool for forest management. submitted to Water Resources Research.

Lumbrazo, C., Bennett, A., Currier, W. R., Nijssen, B., & Lundquist, J. (2021). Evaluating multiple canopy-snow unloading parameterizations in SUMMA with time-lapse photography characterized by citizen scientists. submitted to Water Resources Research.

Mazzotti, G., Currier, W. R., Deems, J. S., Pflug, J. M., Lundquist, J. D., & Jonas, T. (2019). Revisiting snow cover variability and canopy structure within forest stands: Insights from airborne lidar data. Water Resources Research, 55(7), 6198-6216.

Sun, N., Yan, H., Wigmosta, M. S., Lundquist, J., & Dickerson-Lange, S. (2021). Variability of Forest Canopy Effects on Snowpack Dynamics across the Climate Gradients of the Western United States Mountain Ranges. submitted to Water Resources Research.
